'''Johnny Rawls''' (born September 10, 1951)<ref name="Encyc">{{cite web |url=http://www.music.us/biography/artist/25248/johnny_rawls.html |title=Johnny Rawls |author= |date=October 4, 2010 |work=Encyclopedia of Popular Music |publisher=Music.us |accessdate=December 23, 2011}}</ref> is an [[United States|American]] [[soul blues]] singer, guitarist, arranger, songwriter and record producer. He was influenced by the deep soul music of the 1960s, as performed by [[O. V. Wright]], [[James Carr (musician)|James Carr]], and [[Z. Z. Hill]], although his styling, production and lyrics are more contemporary in nature.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Encyc"/>

To date, Rawls has released more than a dozen [[album]]s under his name.<ref name="Albums"/> He has been nominated twelve times for a [[Blues Music Award]].<ref name="Rawls">{{cite web |url=http://www.johnnyrawlsblues.com/Biography.html |title=Johnny Rawls - "Keep the Blues Alive" |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Johnnyrawlsblues.com |accessdate=December 23, 2011}}</ref><ref name="Mark">{{cite web |url=http://www.markpuccimedia.com/johnnyrawls_bio.htm |title=Johnny Rawls - artist bio |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Markpuccimedia.com |accessdate=December 23, 2011}}</ref>

==Life and career==
Rawls was born in [[Hattiesburg, Mississippi]], [[United States]].<ref name="AMG"/><ref group="note">Some sources cite [[Columbia, Mississippi]], as Rawls birth place.</ref> He was taught the rudiments of guitar playing by his blind grandfather, and also played the [[saxophone]] and [[clarinet]] in [[high school]] in [[Purvis, Mississippi]].<ref name="AMG"/> Having mastered guitar playing by his mid teens, Rawls' schoolteacher arranged for him to back musicians who were touring through Mississippi, such as Z. Z. Hill and [[Joe Tex]].  In the mid 1970s, Rawls joined O. V. Wright's backing band, became his music director and played together with Wright until the latter's death in 1980. The band then continued billed as the Ace of Spades Band for another 13 years, and toured and performed with other musicians over this time span.  These included [[B.B. King]], [[Little Milton]], [[Bobby Bland]], [[Little Johnny Taylor]], and [[Blues Boy Willie]].<ref name="AMG"/> The band included the guitarist L.C. Luckett, and he and Rawls jointly released the 1994 album, ''Can't Sleep At Night'', on [[Rooster Blues]].<ref name="Encyc"/> 

His debut solo [[album]], ''Here We Go'', was released on [[JSP Records|JSP]] in 1996. The [[Allmusic]] [[music journalism|journalist]], Thom Owens, noted, "Rawls has a powerful, soulful voice which can make mediocre material sound convincing."<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=here-we-go-r272759|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Here We Go'' > Overview |accessdate=December 23, 2011 |publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref> Rawls also worked as an [[Arrangement|arranger]] and [[record producer]] for JSP.<ref name="Cat"/> Further JSP releases included ''Louisiana Woman'' (1997), ''My Turn to Win'' (1999), and ''Put Your Trust in Me'' (2001), although by the time the latter was issued, Rawls had set up his own label, Deep South Soul.<ref name="Encyc"/> Rawls appeared on the cover of the ''[[Living Blues]]'' magazine in April 2002, where he was  described as "a soul-blues renaissance man".<ref name="Rawls"/><ref name="Cat">{{cite web |url=http://www.catfoodrecords.com/bios-discography.html |title=Johnny Rawls and The Rays |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Catfoodrecords.com |accessdate=December 23, 2011}}</ref> The 2005 release ''No Boundaries'', on Catfood Records increased his profile.<ref name="Cat"/>

His 2006 album ''Heart & Soul'', was nominated for a [[Blues Music Award]] for 'Best Soul Blues Album of the Year'. In the same year, the West Coast Blues Hall of Fame named him 'Best Vocalist'. Rawls has played three times at the [[Chicago Blues Festival]] and plays as many as 15 festivals each year in the US and Canada. He has toured Europe several times as well as Japan and Australia. ''Red Cadillac'' (2008), ''Ace of Spades'' (2010) and ''Memphis Still Got Soul'' (2012) all won the Critics Choice Award for Best Album of the Year in ''Living Blues''. He has also been honored, along with Little Milton and [[Tyrone Davis]], with a Blues Trail Marker in Hattiesburg.<ref name="Rawls"/> The title song of Rawls 2009 album, ''Ace of Spades'', was a tribute to his one time mentor, O. V. Wright.<ref name="Cat"/> The album also garnered Rawls with his first Blues Music Award for 'Best Soul Blues Album of the Year'.<ref name="About">{{cite web |url=http://blues.about.com/od/cddvdreview1/fr/Johnny-Rawls-Memphis-Still-Got-Soul-2011.htm |title=Johnny Rawls - ''Memphis Still Got Soul'' (2011) |author=Reverend Keith A. Gordon |date= |work= |publisher=Blues.about.com |accessdate=December 23, 2011}}</ref>

Rawls album ''Memphis Still Got Soul'', was released in April 2011, his fourth album for Catfood Records.<ref name="Rawls"/><ref name="About"/> It was nominated for 2012 Blues Music Award for Soul Album of the Year, the title song for Song of the Year and Rawls for Male Soul Artist of the Year, his third nomination in that category.  With a further reference to Wright, the album's track listing included Rawls [[cover version|cover]] of the song "Blind, Crippled and Crazy", which was originally associated with Wright.<ref name="Mark"/> His 2012 release, ''Soul Survivor'', included another Wright song, "Eight Men Four Women".  It was nominated for Soul Blues Album of the Year and Rawls was again nominated for Male Soul Artist of the Year at the 2013 Blues Music Awards. His 2013 release on Catfood Records, ''Remembering O.V.'', a tribute to O.V. Wright, featured [[Otis Clay]] as a special guest. ''Remembering O. V.'' was  nominated for 2014 Soul Album of the Year and Rawls for Male Soul Artist of the Year, his 11th and 12th Blues Music Awards nominations.

He is a prolific songwriter with over 100 of his songs recorded.  He has co-produced all of his albums on Catfood Records, as well as [[Barbara Carr]]'s ''Keep The Fire Burning''.
